Comments_List: The course was a good introduction into the methods of Economic History and provided a good overview of the topics discussed. I liked the fact that students had to combine knowledge and methods from different fields to comprehend the material.

Among the mandatory courses in Economics, Tim's course is the only one that discuss endogeneity in a applied context. Since this is one of the most important topics in all applied fields, Tim's course develops an incredibly valuable skill.
Things related to the British industrial revolution.

I gained a better understanding of the economic principles at play in European history, particularly England circa the industrial revolution. For example, I learned more about fertility patterns, how transportation infrastructure developed, and the effect of technology on productivity.
One weakness is the required reading of some very boring papers. I liked the teching style and was pleasantly surprised by the discussions in class.
Very informative. Probably need a paunch line.

Sometimes I felt that the questions addressed by the readings were too narrow. I think the lectures did a good job of covering most of the fundamental things, although sometimes it felt as though the papers were discussed to briefly.
Yes, I would definitely recommedn this course. It is both fun and deep.
Yes, I think it is an interesting course to take if one likes history and would like to learn about some of the connections between economics and history.
